_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



The Plan describes procedures implemented by Wilbur-Ellis Company, Agribusiness Division ("Wilbur-Ellis") to prevent accidental releases of ammonia that could cause harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposures.  The Plan includes an analysis of the potential offsite consequences of an accidental release, a five-year accident history, and a release prevention and emergency response program.  



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Wilbur-Ellis has implemented release prevention and emergency response procedures to minimize the potential for accidental releases of hazardous materials.  Emergency response procedures including evacuation procedures and notification procedures have been implemented by Wilbur-Ellis.  In addition, Wilbur-Ellis has developed operating procedures and preventative maintenance activities to reduce the likelihood of accidental releases.



This Plan and the emergency response procedures document the accidental release prevention, safety, and emergency policies in place at Wilbur-Ellis.



Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



Wilbur-Ellis is located at 101 Highway 7 in White Cloud, Kansas (the "facility").  Wilbur-Ellis is a retailer of fertilizer in the form of anhydrous ammonia stored under pressure.  There are two anhydrous ammonia storage tanks located at the facility with maximum capacities of approximately 18,000 gallons and 12,000 gallons.  The anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the storage tanks into 1,000 gallon nurse tanks.  A maximum total of twelve nurse tanks containing anhydrous ammonia are stored at the facility at any given time.  The contents of the nurse tanks are sold to the local farming community for use as fertilizer.  



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

  

Wilbur-Ellis has developed and implemented this Plan with the objective of complying with the requirements and guidelin

es set forth by the Federal Risk Management Plan program.  The Plan's purpose is to enhance the facility's existing safety programs implemented at the site to reduce the possibility of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia that could cause harm to employees, the public and the environment.  The emergency response program, documented in the emergency response procedures, includes accidental release prevention and chemical specific prevention steps.



Wilbur-Ellis ensures that equipment meets the appropriate industry standards prior to use.  Wilbur-Ellis implements operating procedures and maintenance procedures, in accordance with manufacturer and industry specifications, to prevent accidental releases at the facility.  Chemical specific prevention steps implemented at the site include excess flow valves, pressure relief valves, emergency shut off valves with cables that run along the length of the horizontal storage tanks for quick access, and ammonia training for personnel.

 



Five-Year Accident History



There have been no qualifying accidents involving ammonia in the five-year period prior to the completion of this Plan.



Emergency Response Program



The facility coordinates with the White Cloud Fire Department ("fire department") regarding specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  The facility has established emergency evacuation procedures to evacuate the site and notify the appropriate agencies regarding a release.  The facility's emergency response program is documented in the facility's Emergency Response Procedures.  The emergency procedures contain the following key elements:



1.    Procedures for informing local agencies responsible for responding to accidental releases.

2.    Information on emergency health care.

3.    Emergency response training for employees.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Plans to improve safety at the facility were developed based on the results of a hazard evaluation and

compliance audit by an outside contractor.  The Location Manger is currently working on an implementation schedule for the recommended actions.  Recommended actions include the following:



1.    Install excess flow valves, bleeder valves, and break away valves on the ammonia fill hoses used for the nurse tank filling stations.

2.    Evaluate potential installation of a security system to protect the ammonia process.

3.    Secure the ammonia storage tanks to the saddles.

4.    Document employee training on anhydrous ammonia handling, standard operating procedures and emergency response procedures which will be conducted prior to each of the anhydrous ammonia distribution seasons.

5.    Document that maintenance repairs/replacements performed on the ammonia process are compliant with ANSI, ASME, and OSHA standards for ammonia systems.

6.    Install a wind sock in a prominent location for emergency response and evacuation.

7.    Examine the potential for automatic liquid shut off valves interlocked with the liquid level indicators.

8.    Develop equipment specific replacement schedules and maintain documentation.
